MnO2 as efficient and robust catalyst for halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides Huangfei Liu Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Jia-qi Bai Writing – review & editing Visualization Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Mei Ma Investigation Zhangkai Qian Investigation Mengdie Cai Writing – review & editing Investigation Jingshuai Chen Writing – review & editing Investigation Mingyuan Wu Investigation Yuxue Wei Writing – review & editing Investigation Lisheng Guo Investigation Song Sun Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Anhui University, Hefei, Anhui 230601, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Anhui University Hefei Anhui 230601 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Anhui University, Hefei 230601 Anhui, People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Cyclic carbonate is an important fine chemical/intermediate and their synthesis from CO2 and epoxides is economical and green pathway, however, it is still a challenge to develop a efﬁcient and robust catalyst for halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate. Herein, we successfully prepared large-scale MnO2 catalysts by microfluidics method, and the MnO2 especially δ-MnO2 showed >99.9 % propylene carbonate yield under 393 K, 3 MPa CO2 and DMF solvent. Moreover, the initial TOF value over δ-MnO2 on the basis of total catalyst amount was 5.80 h−1, which was the maximum among all the reported heterogeneous metallic oxide catalysts for halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides, and the superior catalytic performance can be ascribed to the abundant moderate acidic–basic active sites on the δ-MnO2 surface and the synergistic effect of δ-MnO2 and DMF. Furthermore, the δ-MnO2 can be reused at least 4 times and exhibited wide substrate applicability. Graphical Abstract δ-MnO2 catalyst was prepared by microfluidics method and showed superior catalytic performance for halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and propylene oxide. Keywords MnO2 Microfluidics CO2 conversion Cyclic carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 as a greenhouse gas is a critical contributor to global warming because of its increasing concentration in the atmosphere. It is of great interest to utilize CO2 as a cheap, abundant and renewable C1 resource to produce high-value chemicals such as cyclic carbonates [1–7], urea derivatives [8–10], carboxylic acid [11–13] and heterocycles [14–16]. Cyclic carbonate can be used as fuel oil additive, lithium-ion battery electrolyte, organic solvent and basic chemical raw materials [17–20], and its demand rapidly increases with the boom of new energy vehicles and battery energy storage in recent years. Moreover, the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides is one of the more economical and green pathways among these CO2 transformation reactions. Much effort has been devoted to developing effective catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates by scientists. Many homogeneous catalysts showed superior catalytic performance, however, these catalysts are mostly halogen containing and lead to halogen pollution, which influenced the performance of lithium batteries because of the existence of halogens. Moreover, it is different to reuse the homogeneous catalysts. Therefore, the halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides over heterogeneous catalyst is more preferable. The heterogeneous catalyst such as supported ionic liquids [21–24], ion-exchange resins [25,26], functionalized polymers [27–29], metal–organic framework (MOF) materials [30–32], and zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) [33–35] have been reported to show the superior catalytic activity for this reaction, however, the preparation cost of these catalyst is relative expensive and the stability is not satisfying. The price of metal oxide catalysts is relatively low, and some metal oxide catalysts such as CaO [36], ZnO [36], La2O3 [36], Al2O3 [36,37], MgO [38,39], CeO2 [36,40], ZrO2 [36,40], B2O3 [41] and Nb2O5 [42] were prepared for the halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides, however, the activity is relatively low and the reaction conditions is relative harsh. Furthermore, the multimetal oxides such as Cs–P–Si oxide [43], Mn-Ba oxide [44], Sn Ni oxide [44], Ce−La−Zr−O [45], Zr-Mg-O aerogel [46], Mg–Al oxide [47–49] and Zn-Mg-Al-O [49] have been reported for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides without additives of halogen, and they can afford 63.6–96.0 % yield of cyclic carbonate. The Mn-Ba oxide exhibited the highest yield of cyclic carbonate than others metal oxide catalysts. However, the yield (96.0 %) and selectivity (97.9 %) can be further improved. In addition, the structure-activity relationship is still unclear. Therefore, it is significant to develop a novel and efficient metal oxide catalyst and investigate their structure-activity relationship for halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides. On the other hand, MnO2 is low-cost and environment-friendly transition metal oxides, which is a promising heterogeneous catalyst [50]. Sun group reported that MnO2 showed good CO2 activation performance for carbonylation of amines by carbon dioxide [51–53]. However, to our knowledge, the application of MnO2 in halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides have not been reported. We recently prepared threecrystalline forms MnO2 (δ-MnO2, γ-MnO2 and α-MnO2), and especially δ-MnO2 showed superior vulcanizing performance for polysulfide sealing [54,55]. Very recently, we controllably prepared large-scale δ-MnO2, γ-MnO2 and α-MnO2 catalysts by microfluidics method, and the production cost is very low. Herein, we further extended the application of MnO2 catalyst, we found that MnO2 can act as efficient and robust catalyst for halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides for the first time. δ-MnO2 showed >99.9 % propylene carbonate yield with DMF as solvent under 393 K, 3 MPa CO2, which was superior to α-MnO2, γ-MnO2 and other reported metal oxide catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were purchased from chemical companies and used without further purification. Manganese sulfate (Jiangsu Kelundo Food Ingredients Co., Ltd., 99 %), Potassium permanganate (Tianjin Changlu Haijing Group Co., Ltd., 99 %), ethanol (Taicang Hushi Reagent Co., Ltd., 99 %), Ethylene oxide (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 99 %), propylene oxide (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 99 %), 3-hydroxy-1,2-propenoxide (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 97 %), epichlorohydrin (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 99 %), styrene oxide (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 98 %), 2-((propenyloxy)methyl)oxirane (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 99 %), cyclohexene oxide (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 98 %), N, N-Dimethylformamide (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., DMF 99 %), Dioxane (Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 99 %), Methanol (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR), Acetone (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR), Ethyl acetate (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR), Dichloromethane (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR). 2.2 Preparation of MnO2 Synthesis of δ-MnO2: The δ-MnO2 was prepared by microfluidics method as shown in Scheme S1. First, 167 g KMnO4 and 122 g MnSO4 were dissolved in 1 L deionized water in 10 L three-necked flasks, respectively, and then they were heated to 353 K. Subsequently, they were transferred by hastelloy and stainless steel pump with 60.0 mL/min flow rates into tee reactor in oil bath at 353 K. Next, the mixture was collected by vial. Finally, the product δ-MnO2 was obtained by cooling, filtration, washing with deionized water and ethanol twice, drying at 353 K for 24 h and grinding. Synthesis of α-MnO2: The synthesis method of α-MnO2 was the same as that of δ-MnO2, diﬀering only in the amount of KMnO4 (39.5 g) and MnSO4 (75.0 g) and the reaction temperature (363 K). Synthesis of γ-MnO2: γ-MnO2 was prepared using the same procedure for the synthesis of δ-MnO2, diﬀering only in the amount of KMnO4 (26.3 g) and MnSO4 (75.0 g) and the reaction temperature (363 K). 2.3 General procedure of the MnO2 catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides Activity tests were conducted in a 250 mL stainless-steel autoclave (ZNCL-T, Jiadao Intelligent Technology Co., Ltd. Jiangsu). The standard reaction conditions were shown as follows: catalyst (typically 400 mg), spinner, and the mixture of propylene oxide (250 mmol) and N, N-Dimethylformamide (20.0 mL) were added into the autoclave. The air was purged by flushing with CO2 (0.2 MPa) three times after sealing the reactor. Then, 1.5 MPa CO2 was introduced into the autoclave at room temperature, and subsequently the autoclave was heated and the CO2 pressure increased to 3 MPa and the stirring speed was fixed at 500 rpm when the temperature increased to 393 K, and timing was started by the stop watch at the same time. The reactor was cooled to below 278 K in ice bath after the reaction, and extra CO2 was vented slowly. The liquid phase was transferred to a vial and then washed with 10.0 mL of N, N-Dimethylformamide. The products were analyzed by GC (Anhui Chromatography Instrument GC 5190) with an HP-1 capillary column (Agilent Technologies Inc., length = 50 m, I.D. = 0.32 mm, df = 0.52 µm) and diphenyl as an internal standard. The following operating conditions were used: carrier gas: Ar, initial flow rate: 3.00 mL/min, split ratio: 20:1, injection temperature: 553 K, detection temperature: 553 K, column temperature program: 333 K (6 min), 25.0 K/min to 493 K (10 min). The mass balance was also confirmed in each result, and the difference in the mass balance was always in the range of the experimental error (± 5 %). The TOF (h−1) was calculated as follows: TOF (h−1) = (Produced amount of propylene carbonate/mol)/ (total amount of catalyst/mol)/ (reaction time/h). The propylene carbonate formation rate per catalyst gram (V 1, mmol·h−1·g−1), the propylene carbonate formation rate per specific surface area (V 2, mmol·h−1·m−2) and the propylene carbonate formation rate (V 3, mmol·h−1) were calculated as follows: V 1 (mmol·h−1·g−1) = (Produced amount of propylene carbonate/mol)/ (reaction time/h)/ (amount of catalyst/g). V 2 (mmol·h−1·m−2) = (V 1, mmol·h−1·g−1)/ (specific surface area, m2·g−1). V 3 (mmol·h−1) = (Produced amount of propylene carbonate/mol)/ (reaction time/h). The reusability experiment was carried out as follows: first, four group experiments were conducted for the first cycle, then the catalyst was collected for the second cycle by centrifugation, washing with ethyl alcohol and drying, three group experiments were conducted for the second cycle, and subsequently the catalyst was collected by the same method as above-mentioned, two group experiments and one group experiment were carried out for the third cycle and the fourth cycle, respectively. 2.4 Characterization of materials X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a SmartLab 9 kW X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The scanning rate of 0.5° S–1 and the scanning step width of 0.02° were applied in the 2θ range of 5–80°. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were conducted on a field-emission electron microscope (Talos F200S G2, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). Temperature-programmed desorption experiments (NH3-TPD/CO2-TPD) were conducted on an auto adsorption analyzer (AutoChem II 2920, Micromeritics, USA). First, 100 mg of catalyst was treated with pure He gas (30.0 mL/min) at 473 K for 1 h and then cooled to 323 K. Next, the flow of 10.0 % NH3/He with rate of 30.0 mL/min was introduced for 1 h until the adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst was saturated, and then the catalyst was flushed with He gas at 323 K for 1 h. Finally, the catalyst was heated up to 873 K with helium gas flow at rate of 10.0 K/min. The NH3 desorption was monitored by a thermal conductivity (TCD) detector, and the experimental process of CO2-TPD was similar to that of NH3-TPD. The specific surface area and micromesoporous physical adsorption analysis (BET) were conducted on the United States fully automatic ASAP2460 (Mike Instruments). All the specimens were pre-treated at 393 K for 12 h for degassing and tested at 77.0 K. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization result We built the microfluidics equipment in Scheme S1 and controllably prepared large-scale three crystalline forms MnO2 catalysts by the microfluidics method (Details in experiment section). First, XRD was used to investigate the synthetic sample structure. As shown in Fig. 1, the sample 1 exhibited some specific peaks at 12.54°, 25.24°, 37.31°, 40.01° and 66.22°, which was well consistent with that of the (001), (002), (100), (201) and (110) crystal planes of δ-MnO2 (PDF#80–1098), respectively. Furthermore, the fourteen peaks at 12.78°, 18.11°, 25.71°, 28.84°, 37.52°, 39.01°, 41.96°, 47.37°, 49.86°, 56.37°, 60.27°, 65.11°, 69.71° and 72.71° were observed, which can be attributed to the (110), (200), (220), (310), (211), (330), (301), (510), (411), (600), (521), (002), (541) and (312) crystal planes of α-MnO2 (PDF#44–0141), respectively. The sample 3 displayed six peaks at 22.43°, 34.46°, 38.78°, 42.61°, 57.36° and 68.88°, which well matched with that of γ-MnO2 (PDF#14–0644). Therefore, large-scale δ-MnO2, γ-MnO2 and α-MnO2 catalysts were controllably prepared by microfluidics method. Furthermore, the morphology structure was studied by TEM in Fig. 2 δ-MnO2 showed the globe daisy structure composed of nanosheets in Fig. 2a, and the (100), (001) and (002) lattice planes were observed in Fig. 2b, which was well consistent with that of XRD results. α-MnO2 exhibited the nanofiber morphology in Fig. 2c, and typical (211), (200) and (301) crystal planes were shown in Fig. 2d. Cereal-like structure with (131) crystal planes were observed for γ-MnO2 in Fig. 2e and Fig. 2f, which agreed well with that of XRD results. In a word, δ-MnO2, γ-MnO2 and α-MnO2 catalysts were successfully prepared by microfluidics method. Figure S1 showed the BET surface area analysis of δ-MnO2, α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms showed a distinct characteristic hysteresis loop at P/P0 of more than 0.4 for δ-MnO2, α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 in Figure S1a, indicating that the δ-MnO2, α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 samples featured mesoporous property. Furthermore, the specific surface areas were 124, 80.7 and 63.2 m2 g−1 for δ-MnO2, α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2, and Figure S1b showed the pore diameter was 8.70, 31.1 and 16.6 nm for δ-MnO2, α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2, respectively. The δ-MnO2 showed the largest specific surface, which was conducive to the adsorption of substrate and thereby improved the catalytic performance. The surface acid-base properties of MnO2 were investigated by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3a, δ-MnO2, α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 all showed several NH3 desorption peaks for NH3-TPD, which can be divided into weak (373–473 K), moderate (473–673 K), and strong adsorption (673–873 K) of NH3 [40,56]. The corresponding NH3 desorption amount was shown in Table 1, δ-MnO2 showed the highest moderate acidic amount followed by α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2. The CO2-TPD profile was similar as that of NH3-TPD in Fig. 3b, and the desorption peaks at 373–473 K, 473–673 K and 673–873 K were ascribed to weak, moderate, and strong adsorption of CO2 [40,56]. Furthermore, the corresponding basic amount was shown in Table 2, δ-MnO2 also exhibited the largest moderate basic amount followed by α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2. In a word, δ-MnO2 showed the largest moderate acidic and basic amount followed by α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2. 3.2 Catalyst screening for the synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and propylene oxide At ﬁrst, we investigated the catalytic performance of various metal oxides for the halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides. As shown in Fig. 4 and Table S1, the blank experiment without catalyst and solvent only showed 0.212 % propylene oxide conversion. However, 2.49 % propylene oxide conversion and >99.9 % selectivity were obtained with only DMF as solvent, which can be ascribed to the activation of CO2 and propylene oxide by DMF. Furthermore, the introduction of metallic oxide catalyst can be employed to increase the activity. Nb2O5 showed 3.36 % conversion and >99.9 % selectivity to propylene carbonate, ZrO2, MgO, Al2O3 and CeO2 showed 3.45 %, 3.32 %, 5.72 % and 4.21 %, however, only 98.4 %, 96.6 %, 98.6 % and 99.2 % selectivity to cyclic carbonate were obtained for these catalysts, respectively. The small amount of 1, 2-propylene diol and acetone were observed for CeO2, ZrO2 and MgO catalysts, and acetone and propanal was observed for Al2O3 catalyst. Interestingly, all the MnO2 showed excellent selectivity, especially δ-MnO2 showed 10.6 % conversion and >99.9 % selectivity to propylene carbonate, which was superior to the other tested metallic oxide catalysts. In addition, no product was observed with DMF only under 363 K. However, δ-MnO2 catalyst showed 2.78 % conversion, indicating that δ-MnO2 was main active phase for this reaction. Therefore, δ-MnO2 was selected as the candidate catalyst in terms of conversion and selectivity in the following research. The time course for halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides was shown in Fig. 5a and Table S2. The reaction proceeded smoothly to reach >99.9 % conversion over δ-MnO2 at 24 h, and the selectivity to propylene carbonate remained >99.9 % and no byproduct was observed during reaction (Table S2). Furthermore, the initial TOF value for δ-MnO2 on the basis of total catalyst amount was 5.80 h−1 at low conversion under 393 K, 3 MPa CO2, which was the maximum among all the tested metallic oxide catalysts, and to our best knowledge, the TOF is the highest among the reported heterogeneous metallic oxide catalysts for halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides (Table S3). Furthermore, the reusability of the δ-MnO2 was investigated under 393 K, 3 MPa CO2 in Fig. 5b and Table S4 at 1 h. The δ-MnO2 catalyst was recycled after drying without additional treatment. The conversion was 10.6 %, 10.0 %, 9.60 % and 10.2 % for the first, second, third and fourth run, respectively, and the propylene carbonate selectivity of >99.9 % was not changed (Table S4, entries 1–4). Moreover, the reusability was carried out at high conversion (Table S5, entries 1–4), the conversion and selectivity were not changed. Furthermore, XRD patterns of δ-MnO2 before and after the reaction was almost not changed (Figure S2), indicating that δ-MnO2 was a durable and reusable heterogeneous catalyst. 3.3 Scope of substrates over δ-MnO2 Next, the scope of the cycloaddition of CO2 with various epoxides over δ-MnO2 was investigated under 393 K, 3 MPa CO2 at 24 h in Table 3, ethylene oxide and propylene oxide were selectively converted to corresponding cyclic carbonate with >99.9 % yield (Entry 1 and 2). For epoxides with low steric hindrance such as oxiranyl-methanol and epichlorohydrin, the 94.2 % and 95.0 % yield to corresponding cyclic carbonate were obtained (Entry 3 and 4). Furthermore, styrene oxide and 2-allyloxymethyl-oxirane were also efficiently transformed to corresponding cyclic carbonate with yield of 90.1 % and 86.4 % (Entry 5 and 6). 75.6 % cyclic carbonate yield was obtained at 24 h even when cyclohexene oxide with bulky steric hindrance was used as the substrate (Entry 7). Moreover, the yield to cyclic carbonate was higher than that over the reported metallic oxide catalysts [44,57,58]. In a word, δ-MnO2 exhibited not only superior catalytic activity and chemoselectivity but also wide substrate scope. 3.4 Structure-activity relationship The correlation between the activity and specific surface area was investigated in Figure S3 and Tables 1–2. The propylene carbonate formation rate per gram of catalyst (V 1) and the specific surface area were fitted, and a superior linear relationship with R2 = 0.982 were obtained, which strongly indicated that the catalytic activity was related to the specific surface area. Furthermore, the total acidic amount from NH3-TPD profiles for MnO2 decreased as follows: δ-MnO2>γ-MnO2>α-MnO2. However, the propylene carbonate formation rate per specific surface area (V 2) showed different trend as that of total acidic amount in Figure S4a and Table 1, indicating that total acidic sites were not the active site. Meanwhile, the basic amount from CO2-TPD profiles showed the same trend as that of acidic amount: δ-MnO2>γ-MnO2>α-MnO2, however, the propylene carbonate formation rate per specific surface area (V 2) showed different trend as that of total basic amount in Figure S4b and Table 2, suggesting that total basis sites were also not the active site. Furthermore, the relationship between activity and the weak acid/base sites and strong acid/base sites were investigated in Figure S4c-f and Tables 1–2. The propylene carbonate formation rate per specific surface area (V 2) and the amount of weak acidic/basic and strong acidic/basic sites were fitted in Figure S4 and Tables 1–2, respectively, however, no good linear relationships with high R2 were obtained, which indicated that the total acidic/basic, weak acidic/basic and strong acidic/basic sites were not the active sites for this catalytic reaction. In addition, the propylene carbonate formation rate per specific surface area (V 2) and the moderate acidic and basic amount were fitted in Fig. 6 and Tables 1–2, respectively, and two superior linear relationships of R2 = 0.997 and 0.992 were obtained, strongly indicating that the moderate acid and base were the active sites for this catalytic reaction, which was well consistent with that Wang's work in the halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonates over CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution where the moderate acidic and basic sites acted as the major active sites [40]. Furthermore, considering that the strong acidic/basic sites will prevent the desorption of product and the weak acidic/basic sites will lead to weak adsorption strength of substrate, and the moderate adsorption strength will contribute to the good catalytic performance on moderate acidic/basic sites. Therefore, the moderate acid and base were the active sites for this catalytic reaction. 3.5 Kinetics study Solvents often plays dramatic role in transformation reactions of CO2 to chemicals [59,60]. As shown in Fig. 7 and Table S6, δ-MnO2 showed 2.38 % conversion with >99.9 % selectivity to propylene carbonate in the absence of solvent. δ-MnO2 only exhibited 1.39 % conversion with dichloromethane as solvent, which can be ascribed to the fact that the dilution effect by dichloromethane solvent can decrease the activity. However, the other solvent such as ethyl acetate, methanol, dioxane, acetone and DMF all showed position effect on the catalytic performance, providing 2.52 %, 2.75 %, 3.02 %, 4.23 % and 10.6 % conversion, respectively. DMF solvent showed the much higher activity than that of the other solvents. Furthermore, only DMF solvent without catalyst showed 2.49 % conversion, indicating that CO2 and propylene oxide can be activated by DMF [42,44,61]. However, the MnO2 catalyst with DMF as solvent showed larger conversion than the sum of that over MnO2 without solvent (2.38 %) and only DMF solvent without catalyst (2.49 %), indicating that MnO2 and DMF solvent showed synergistic effect for halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides, which was well consistent with that of previous reports [42,44,61,62]. Therefore, DMF was employed as solvent for the following research. In order to explore the reaction kinetics over δ-MnO2 for the halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides, the effect of epoxides concentration and CO2 pressure were investigated. Firstly, the effect of stirring speed on catalytic performance was shown in Table S7, the conversion was 8.26 %, 10.2 %, 10.6 % and 10.7 % over δ-MnO2 at stirring speed of 300 rpm, 400 rpm, 500 rpm and 700 rpm, respectively. Therefore, the kinetic experiment can be carried out within kinetic region at 500 rpm. The effect of propylene oxide concentration was shown in the range from 6.67 to 2.13 M in Fig. 8a and Table S8. The TOF gradually increased with the increase of propylene oxide concentration, and the reaction order over δ-MnO2 with DMF as solvent was 1.66, indicating that the adsorption of propylene oxide was weak on the catalyst surface and involved in the rate-determining step. Furthermore, the effect of CO2 pressure was investigated at 1.5, 3 and 5 MPa in Fig. 8b and Table S10. The TOF was almost same at each concentration, and the reaction order was estimated to be 0.0419 for δ-MnO2, indicating that the adsorption of CO2 was adequately saturated over δ-MnO2 with DMF as solvent. In order to ascertain the roles of δ-MnO2 and DMF individually, the effect of CO2 pressure and propylene oxide concentration was investigated using δ-MnO2 in dchloromethane, DMF only and without MnO2 and DMF in Table 4 and the details were shown in Fig. 8, Figure S6-S7 and Table S8-S14. In the case of δ-MnO2 in dchloromethane, dchloromethane was employed as the solvent because dchloromethane showed the small effect on the activity and selectivity. The reaction orders were 1.97 and 0.0549 with respect to propylene oxide concentration and CO2 pressure over δ-MnO2 in dchloromethane solvent, respectively (entry 2). Furthermore, the reaction order with respect to CO2 pressure over MnO2 in dchloromethane was lower than those without δ-MnO2 and DMF (0.123, entries 2 and 4) and DMF only (0.0723, entries 2 and 4) and almost same as that over MnO2 in DMF (0.0419, entries 2 and 4), suggesting that δ-MnO2 and DMF all can decrease the reaction orders with respect to CO2 pressure and CO2 were mainly adsorbed on the surface of δ-MnO2 over δ-MnO2 in DMF solvent. On the other hand, the reaction order was 2.43 with respect to propylene oxide concentration for DMF only (entry 3) and it was decreased to 1.97 over δ-MnO2 in dchloromethane and 1.66 over δ-MnO2 in DMF, indicating that MnO2 and DMF showed synergistic effect for propylene oxide activation. Furthermore, the rate equation can be calculated using the experimental data (Table S2 entries 1–4), it can be expressed as follows: r=0.0303c1.66, which was well consistent with the reaction order of 1.66 with respect to propylene oxide concentration. From these results, it can be found that δ-MnO2 and DMF concertedly worked for activation of propylene oxide, and CO2 was mainly activated by δ-MnO2. The eﬀect of the reaction temperature was investigated between 373 and 413 K, and the Arrhenius plots were shown in Fig. 9 (details are given in Table S15 and Table S16). The apparent activation energy E a was estimated to be 81.4 kJ mol−1 with DMF only. However, the apparent activation energy E a over δ-MnO2 with DMF as solvent was estimated to be 64.9 kJ mol−1, the δ-MnO2 decreased the activation energy, indicating that δ-MnO2 was the important active phase for this reaction and δ-MnO2 and DMF can synergistically catalyze this reaction, which agreed well with the result in Fig. 4. Moreover, the E a over δ-MnO2 with DMF as solvent is comparable to those of the reported catalysts (Table S17). Furthermore, the frequency factor A was estimated to be 2.66×109 and 1.32×109 h−1 for δ-MnO2 with DMF as solvent and DMF only on the basis of Arrhenius equation in Fig. 9, respectively, indicating that δ-MnO2 in DMF can increase the collision frequency and thereby contributing to the superior catalytic performance. Therefore, δ-MnO2 exhibited superior catalytic performance for halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides with DMF as solvent. 4 Conclusion Large-scale δ-MnO2, γ-MnO2 and α-MnO2 were successfully prepared by microfluidics method and applied as catalyst for halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides. MnO2 especially δ-MnO2 showed >99.9 % propylene carbonate yield with DMF as solvent under 393 K, 3 MPa CO2, the initial TOF value over δ-MnO2 on the basis of total catalyst amount was 5.80 h−1, which was the maximum among all the reported heterogeneous metallic oxide catalysts for halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides, and the superior catalytic performance can be ascribed to the abundant moderate acidic–basic active sites on the δ-MnO2 surface and the synergistic effect of δ-MnO2 and DMF. Furthermore, the δ-MnO2 can be reused at least 4 times and exhibited wide substrate applicability. This work not only provides a general strategy to prepare large-scale MnO2, but also extends the application of MnO2 catalyst in CO2 conversion field. coredata.dc:description: Cyclic carbonate is an important fine chemical/intermediate and their synthesis from CO2 and epoxides is economical and green pathway, however, it is still a challenge to develop a efﬁcient and robust catalyst for halogen-free synthesis of cyclic carbonate. Herein, we successfully prepared large-scale MnO2 catalysts by microfluidics method, and the MnO2 especially δ-MnO2 showed >99.9 % propylene carbonate yield under 393 K, 3 MPa CO2 and DMF solvent. Moreover, the initial TOF value over δ-MnO2 on the basis of total catalyst amount was 5.80 h−1, which was the maximum among all the reported heterogeneous metallic oxide catalysts for halogen-free synthesis of propylene carbonate from CO2 and epoxides, and the superior catalytic performance can be ascribed to the abundant moderate acidic–basic active sites on the δ-MnO2 surface and the synergistic effect of δ-MnO2 and DMF. Furthermore, the δ-MnO2 can be reused at least 4 times and exhibited wide substrate applicability.
